moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nc3: The fact alone that I live in Vienna myself makes that opening very attractive for me ;-)
moves.2... Nf6 3. f4: Alright, let's experiment, this is called the "Vienna gambit (C29)".
moves.3... exf4: Instead of taking, more common is 3... d5.
moves.4. Nf3 Qe7: My pawn on e4 is attacked...
moves.5. e5: ... so let's go for a counter-attack on his knight.
moves.6. Nxd5: Of course, I take the free knight and attack the opponent's queen at the same time.
moves.6... Qe6 7. Nxf4: Again taking material and attacking the queen.
moves.7... Qf5 8. d4: Defending the knight and occupying the center.
moves.8... Qe4+ 9. Qe2: Being ahead of material, I don't have anything against a queen exchange.
moves.10... d5 11. O-O-O: 11. exd6 e.p.+ would also have been a very nice move.
moves.11... Bf5 12. Qb5+: Now that the point b7 is undefended, I exploit that.
moves.12... Nc6 13. Qxb7 Rd8 14. Qxc7: Qxc6 would have been better, but the game is not very interesting any more anyway.
moves.15. Qxc6+ Rd7 16. Qxc2: At this point my opponent resigned. This is a first success with the Vienna Game. It is clear that my win doesn't have anything to do with the opening - my opponent just blundered, but hey, this encourages me to try out the Vienna Game (or Vienna Gambit) more often in the future anyway!

gameName: Adventures with the Vienna Game - Part I
